request.description: Creates a single __drug__ as defined in the json body of the request

This also showcases how we can also give the list of visits
and it will automatically create both. 
Notes : If drug objects (in json) have an id property only, they're retrieved; otherwise new drug entities will be created.

item.name: 3. Add New Visit To Returning Patient

request.description:
To set the returning patient we can either do it like this request (using pid as GET param) or use the path variable at /visits/patient/{pid}

**Note** The same as when we created the patient, if the drugs are referenced by ID they're retrieved, otherwise they're created.
All list and search implement paging, just add the optional count and page GET request parameters to select page count and number respectively.

Body Example (id mandatory) : 
{
    "id": 1,
    "name": "Rami Anastas",
    "birthday": "2015-01-01",
    "male": false,
    "address": "702 nguyen van linh",
    "visits": []
}

Body Example (id mandatory) : 
{
    "id": 1,
    "name": "Rami Anastas",
    "birthday": "2015-01-01",
    "male": false,
    "address": "702 nguyen van linh",
    "visits": []
}

Body Example (id mandatory) : 
{
    "id": 1,
    "name": "Rami Anastas",
    "birthday": "2015-01-01",
    "male": false,
    "address": "702 nguyen van linh",
    "visits": []
}
Doesn't work. Because ReferenceFixer doesn't check if Visit from json attribute has an ID to retrieve and link appropriately..

Body Example (id mandatory) : 
{
    "id": 1,
    "name": "Rami Anastas",
    "birthday": "2015-01-01",
    "male": false,
    "address": "702 nguyen van linh",
    "visits": []
}
Basically searches prescriptions based on what's inside the instructions.
